title: At Least 6 Are Dead in a Walmart Shooting in Virginia; Assailant is also dead after shooting, police say, in the state's second mass shooting in less than two weeks
text:
The shooting happened at the Walmart Supercenter, a bigger version of a Walmart store, less than an hour before its 11 p.m. closing time during a busy Thanksgiving shopping week. The store is about 5 miles south of Norfolk.

Mr. Kosinski said that over the course of about 30 to 45 minutes, responding officers found multiple dead and injured people.

He said he didn't know how many people were injured. Police didn't identify the victims.

In a statement early Wednesday, Walmart Inc. said it was working closely with law-enforcement agencies.

"We are shocked at this tragic event at our Chesapeake, Virginia store," Walmart said on Twitter. "We're praying for those impacted, the community and our associates."

A Walmart spokesman declined to comment beyond the company's statement early Wednesday.

Chesapeake Mayor Rick W. West said the community has been shaken by the attack.

"I am devastated by the senseless act of violence that took place last night in our city. My prayers are with all those affected—the victims, their family, their friends and their co-workers," he said on Twitter. "I am grateful for the quick actions taken by our first responders who rushed to the scene."

Virginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin said on Twitter Wednesday morning that he has been in contact with law-enforcement officials about the events in Chesapeake.

"Our hearts break with the community of Chesapeake this morning," he said. "Heinous acts of violence have no place in our communities."

The city of Chesapeake said a news conference would be held at 8 a.m. ET on Wednesday.

The mass shooting is Virginia's second in less than two weeks. On Nov. 13, a gunman killed three people and injured two otherson the University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville. A suspect, a UVA student, was taken into custody after a nearly 13-hour manhunt.

Late Saturday, a gunman opened fire in a gay nightclub in Colorado Springs, Colo., killing five people and wounding an additional 19.

The suspect, Anderson Lee Aldrich, was arrested on murder and hate-crime charges in the massacre at Club Q, which was hosting a drag show. The club had planned a brunch for Sunday in honor of Transgender Day of Remembrance.

He is scheduled to make his first court appearance Wednesday.

Including the shooting at the Virginia Walmart, there have been more than 600 mass shootings in the U.S. so far this year, according to the Gun Violence Archive, a nonprofit that tracks U.S. shootings. The organization defines a mass shooting as a situation in which at least four people are shot, excluding the shooter.

—Thomas Derpinghaus contributed to this article.

Write to Alyssa Lukpat at alyssa.lukpat@wsj.com

At Least 6 Are Dead in a Walmart Shooting in Virginia
